story:
★This campaign was launched on 12/12/2012 at 12:12:12EST ★

The Story - Two Mistakes Two Many

Have you ever had such a strange case of deja vu that you could swear that you were in another place, in another time?  If so, could it be possible to be an entirely different person?

Two Mistakes Two Many is the story of a young man named Yatsurao Satoru, who, in trying to save his village under the threat of war, is forced to leave his home and search for the lost legacy of Keitaro Yoshitsune; the only man in all of history to accidentally relive the life of Buddha.

It's come to be that Two Mistakes Two Many has been regarded as a little less of a conventional graphic novel, and a little more a black and white film on paper.  So sit back and enjoy the show, with a warm cup of tea on a late Saturday night, folks.

My Mission

This is my first graphic novel, however, not it's debut.  I first released the book in August, 2012.  It's debut was a success, and I have only one copy left (the one for myself, that is).  With this campaign, I aim to reprint Book One, as well as debut Book Two, so that I can continue to share this story that I've written, destroyed, and rewritten many times over.  

What's Good in the Hood?

All pledges will be used to cover printing and shipping costs for both Book One and Book Two. Check them out:

                                          

  • $12 (MARK-I): 1 signed  copy (personalised to you) of Two Mistakes Two Many - Book One {104 Pages}

                              

  • $15 (MARK-II): 1 signed copy (personalised to you) of Two Mistakes Two Many - Book Two {180 Pages}

  • Please note that this is a Canadian campaign, and all packages will only be shipped within Canada and the United States.

   

And if you're wondering what happens if I don't quite reach my financial goal or exceed it, don't worry about it.  In the event of falling a bit short, there will be no problems on your end; what you ordered is what you'll get!  And if I surpass my goal, simple: I'll produce more books so that I can continue to spread this story as far as words can reach!

★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★

*Your 15 Minutes of Fame*

If by February 8th, 2013 you order the "You're the Star" package, you will join the universe of Two Mistakes Two Many as a background character in Book Two, Chapter 6 - Light of the Black Sun.  

I know that I've always wanted to be a comic book hero, and that's exactly why I decided to sneak myself into this adventure as Yatsurao Satoru, of course.  I get to go on all the wild adventures I always dreamed of.  And better yet, I get to share them with everyone!  There's a scene in Chapter 6 where Keitaro ends up in a hot and grimy market place in Shadipur, India.  This is where you come in, with a chance to become a part of the pages of manga history!  Amongst the shady merchants and customers, dealers and snake charmers, will be you as a special guest background character!  And just so you can see that priceless look on your friends' faces when they don't believe that you have a cameo in my story, I'll also draw a full colour 8.5"x11" portrait of your character (you know, just so you can prove it, and make them eat their words)!

★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★

Just so you Know

No writers.  No Inkers. No publisher down ma' neck.  What you see is 100% a product of my hard work over the last two years of my life.  And just so you know (and probably as you've guessed), book three is on it's way!

How you can Help

If you really like what you're seeing but just can't afford to get a copy of the book right now, don't worry folks!  This story is too special to just keep to myself, so I've finally released Two Mistakes Two Many - Book One online (which you can read for free) at:

http://twomistakestwomany.smackjeeves.com/

Hope you like it.  And if you do, please tell your friends!  Sharing is caring after all, and to me, digital sharing can make all the difference.  Facebook, blogs, Tumblr, Twitter, spread the word if you like what you see!  And make sure to use the indiegogo share tools, too!


For more of my art, come check me out:

Blog - http://justfeelingfine.blogspot.ca/

deviantArts - http://raging-akujiki.deviantart.com/

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For all custom 8.5"x11" drawings, please feel free to shoot me an e-mail at: naseer.pasha88@gmail.com.  Be sure to write in the subject line, "TMTM Drawing" and write me a small description (with possible reference pic links) of which package you ordered and what you'd like drawn, and I'll work me magic!  

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Commission Samples - 8.5"x11"
story_txt:
★This campaign was launched on 12/12/2012 at 12:12:12EST ★

The Story - Two Mistakes Two Many

Have you ever had such a strange case of deja vu that you could swear that you were in another place, in another time?  If so, could it be possible to be an entirely different person?
Two Mistakes Two Many is the story of a young man named Yatsurao Satoru, who, in trying to save his village under the threat of war, is forced to leave his home and search for the lost legacy of Keitaro Yoshitsune; the only man in all of history to accidentally relive the life of Buddha.
It's come to be that Two Mistakes Two Many has been regarded as a little less of a conventional graphic novel, and a little more a black and white film on paper.  So sit back and enjoy the show, with a warm cup of tea on a late Saturday night, folks.
My Mission
This is my first graphic novel, however, not it's debut.  I first released the book in August, 2012.  It's debut was a success, and I have only one copy left (the one for myself, that is).  With this campaign, I aim to reprint Book One, as well as debut Book Two, so that I can continue to share this story that I've written, destroyed, and rewritten many times over.  


What's Good in the Hood?
All pledges will be used to cover printing and shipping costs for both Book One and Book Two. Check them out:
                                          



$12 (MARK-I): 1 signed  copy (personalised to you) of Two Mistakes Two Many - Book One {104 Pages}

                          



$15 (MARK-II): 1 signed copy (personalised to you) of Two Mistakes Two Many - Book Two {180 Pages}




Please note that this is a Canadian campaign, and all packages will only be shipped within Canada and the United States.



   
And if you're wondering what happens if I don't quite reach my financial goal or exceed it, don't worry about it.  In the event of falling a bit short, there will be no problems on your end; what you ordered is what you'll get!  And if I surpass my goal, simple: I'll produce more books so that I can continue to spread this story as far as words can reach!
★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★


*Your 15 Minutes of Fame*
If by February 8th, 2013 you order the "You're the Star" package, you will join the universe of Two Mistakes Two Many as a background character in Book Two, Chapter 6 - Light of the Black Sun.  
I know that I've always wanted to be a comic book hero, and that's exactly why I decided to sneak myself into this adventure as Yatsurao Satoru, of course.  I get to go on all the wild adventures I always dreamed of.  And better yet, I get to share them with everyone!  There's a scene in Chapter 6 where Keitaro ends up in a hot and grimy market place in Shadipur, India.  This is where you come in, with a chance to become a part of the pages of manga history!  Amongst the shady merchants and customers, dealers and snake charmers, will be you as a special guest background character!  And just so you can see that priceless look on your friends' faces when they don't believe that you have a cameo in my story, I'll also draw a full colour 8.5"x11" portrait of your character (you know, just so you can prove it, and make them eat their words)!
★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★★
Just so you Know
No writers.  No Inkers. No publisher down ma' neck.  What you see is 100% a product of my hard work over the last two years of my life.  And just so you know (and probably as you've guessed), book three is on it's way!


How you can Help
If you really like what you're seeing but just can't afford to get a copy of the book right now, don't worry folks!  This story is too special to just keep to myself, so I've finally released Two Mistakes Two Many - Book One online (which you can read for free) at:
http://twomistakestwomany.smackjeeves.com/
Hope you like it.  And if you do, please tell your friends!  Sharing is caring after all, and to me, digital sharing can make all the difference.  Facebook, blogs, Tumblr, Twitter, spread the word if you like what you see!  And make sure to use the indiegogo share tools, too!
For more of my art, come check me out:
Blog - http://justfeelingfine.blogspot.ca/
deviantArts - http://raging-akujiki.deviantart.com/
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For all custom 8.5"x11" drawings, please feel free to shoot me an e-mail at: naseer.pasha88@gmail.com.  Be sure to write in the subject line, "TMTM Drawing" and write me a small description (with possible reference pic links) of which package you ordered and what you'd like drawn, and I'll work me magic!  
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Commission Samples - 8.5"x11"

story:
Hello,

 

I am an aspiring comic artist and writer from Winnipeg, Manitoba. I hope to begin self publishing my first comic / graphic novel under the publishing name 'Anonymi Press' by the end of September.
I am looking to get approximately 100 to 200 copies printed. Once I get a few books printed and a flow going, I will work on continuing the catalog that Anonymi Press has to offer.

 

I am running this campaign to raise $1000 to get me started. I'm not asking for much and this is more than enough to get me off the ground. I need approximately $500 - $600 to get 100 copies made. (that's about $5 - $6 per book to print).

 

I am offering my skills as an artist to any contributor in various ways. Please view perks for your options. If a contribution is made, I ask that you send me an email at project_anonymus@hotmail.com with a picture of yourself (for the purpose of doing a comic portrait) and a mailing address to send the requested item.

 

If you are uncomfortable giving a photo graph, I can certainly incorperate that into the sketch itself (via mask, etc.). If you do not with to provide a mailing address, I can certainly provide a digital copy of your art.

 

All art will be show cased on my facebook page here: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Comic-Portrait-project/367886473267740

 

100% of the funding will go toward getting the Tempest Moon printed.

 

If you have any questions regarding the campaign or the perks, please forward your questions to the email address above.

 

I would also very much appreciate the help in spreading the word. I have facebook and twitter accounts linked to this campaign. Please like, share, follow or hashtag to help get the word out.

 

Thank you very much for your time!

story:
The Story So Far...

Thank you for reading this, I'm Keith (indi) and I'm an artist making digital prints with a passion for strong women. I grew up reading comic books and have been drawing pinups for years. 

I've been trying to make work that shows what I find attractive in the women in my life. They tend to be very tough and sexy in different ways then what I see in most media. Most of them don't have media defined perfect bodies, or normal society stereotype defined interests. That's what really makes them amazing to me and what I'm trying to show in my work. 

For a long time I wasn't showing my work, but recently a friend of mine convinced me to start putting it out there. So far my work has been finding interest at local events (charity shows and art fairs) I've been entering it into.  I can use some help though...

Right now my work has become self supporting to a degree. The art has been selling well enough to cover the costs of entering shows and supplies to make more art, but not enough to offer more diverse products to sell my customers and definitely not enough to pay my household expenses.

That's where you come in. I'm looking for money to make an initial print run of comic books and vinyl stickers to sell.  My hope is that profits I can make off of the first set of books and stickers will be able to generate enough to cover costs on putting out more future comics, and maybe even some day be able to pay the occasional bill at home.

I have enough content for three comic books, and a lot of extra pinup art. While I will be able to get it all out there eventually, your help will really speed up the process. As a way of thanks, before they ever get printed, I'll be giving out digital downloads of all three issues along with art prints and the original drawings they were all scanned from.

Issue #1 features a story about a girl battling robots in the post apocalypse along with bonus pinups, and is relatively family friendly.

Issue #2 is a bit spicier. The story includes masturbation, vampires, fortune tellers, and a giant squid.

Issue #3 is not for the kids, but us old folks might enjoy it. It's my attempt at erotica and is completely painted in inkwash as opposed to the usual marker drawing I'm known for. 

If I  can make my full goal of $500, it will cover a first print of 100 copies of issue #1 and run of about 250 stickers after printing and fees.

12/5/14 Update: The money raised so far has afforded me a print run of about 20 copies of issue #1, so everyone who contributes $5 or more will also receive a physical comic book.

Even if I can't make my full goal, your funding would still be able to help me order a more modest print run which would lead to bigger things someday. If I can't make my full goal I won't be able to include physical printed copies of the book or stickers so there is a slight risk. However, all of the other rewards including digital downloads of my comics, original drawings, prints, and commission pieces will still be fulfilled either way. 

Thank you for your time, and even if you can't please help me by passing word along about my plan.

story:
What's up? What's happening? Wah Blow?

Hi, my name is Glen Waters and I'm a freelance marketer based in North London. Before I took my leap of faith and became self employed, I worked for a terribly uninspiring organisation. With nothing to sink my teeth in to professionally I began writing comedy music in my spare time, in an effort to stay sane and smiling.

 I released one of these tracks through my alter ego Kai Bo. The track was called Arse Out! and with the help of some pretty amazing friends I managed to shoot a video. The result, well, it sort of went viral. A little bit anyway.

The sense of achievement I felt was really quite special and to have genuinely made that many people smile is something I'm really proud of.  The story was actually picked up by the Sun Newspaper and then by Chanel 4's RudeTube, and to date the video has achieved no less than 135,000 views online. That's platinum on YouTube according to my friend Wes. 

Naturally, I'd love to do it again so I've written some songs and I'm ready to go.  Only thing holding me back is resource. I can't beg, borrow and steal from my friends all over again so I've come to the crowd for help.  I need £1250 in order to shoot two music videos with a touch built in for contingency. Money will be used to fund lights, camera and as much action as I can muster. Oh, and if I don't make my goal you get your dough back.

So the songs.. We'll, I've got:

  • one about falling in love at a festival called Smelly Welly Boots
  • one about turning 30 called LIMP
  • one about polishing your trumpet called Real woman. We all know polishing your trumpet doesn't actually mean polishing your trumpet, right? 
 There are some pretty cool perks for you guys if you fancied getting involved, so if you thought my first effort was funny then please help out as much as you can so I can rerun the fun.
Also don't forget to share this for me and really make some noise about my campaign. Click the share button and let the world know about Kai Bo the Funky Chav. Myself and the man himself really appreciate it. 
Safe! (that's street for thank you),

Glen & Kai.

story:
An Introduction to Era

Hi, my name is Scott B Henderson and The Chronicles of Era  is the first three chapters in an epic fantasy graphic novel.

Book I of The Chronicles of Era: Whispers of Redemption will introduce readers to a world where mankind made for himself a paradise fit for gods. Mankind lived in the City of Heaven for two thousand years before The Adversary destroyed paradise and returned humanity to a harsh and brutal world. The survivors rebuilt their civilization, but their history was reduced to myths and legends. Hundreds of years later, three youths—Seth, Sidrich and Caitleth—are caught between the struggles of a great empire and the scattered rural clans struggling to maintain their way of life. 

 All the while, secret forces are edging closer to awakening the Gifted Ones and reopen the gates of a lost paradise...

The Graphic Novel

The Chronicles of Era: Whispers of Redemption Book I  is 104 pages. The art is black and white line art, except for the three chapter breaks (they were to be the original covers for each chapter) which are coloured. Included at the end is a glossary and world map. Perfect bound, soft cover, approximately 7"x10.25"

The Chronicles of Era graphic novel debuted at the Central Canada Comic Con (C4), 2014.

Here are some generous words from a recent review on Goodreads by L.T. Getty:

"I won't talk too much about the story here, on account that it's pretty epic and the story builds up a lot and leaves us with few answers - it's set against two very different religious cultures, some choosing to live and trade despite the uneasiness and difference between the people, others forcing their beliefs and fighting. Kudos on the balls for talking about religion and conversion - you can draw parallels to our own world, but it's not necessary reading into it to enjoy the story."



Era's History and Influences

The Chronicles of Era has a long history. In its infancy it was science fiction story—populated by cyborgs, Frankenstein genetic experiments and trans-dimensional priests—before transforming into its current form, a more mythic fantasy world that still retains elements of sci-fi adventure and bits of steampunk.  The world was heavily influenced by Frank Herbert's Dune , Tad William's Memory, Sorrow, Thorn Trilogy , Michael Moorcock's Corum, but also by the books of Daniel Quinn, anthropology and mythology.  It was a few more years before the story was refined to a point where I could say, "This is it. For good or bad, this is the story that will be told."

My Background

I've been drawing since childhood, and even at an early age I drew pictures to stories. In high school and university I met a few exceptional teachers who had a profound influence on me.  After receiving my bachelor of Fine Arts from the University of Manitoba, I worked on digitally colouring comic books, working in custom framing and all the while continuing to experiment and refine my storytelling. To date, I've illustrated nine graphic novels for Canadian publishers and educators, including: 7 Generations: A Plains Cree Saga (which was nominated for best illustrated book in the 2013 Manitoba Book Awards), Sugar Falls and three stories for Tales from Big Spirit and most recently Betty: The Helen Betty Osborne Story.

What We Need & What You Get

The art for The Chronicles of Era has already been completed! All that remains is lettering the last chapter, creating a new cover for the first book and editing.  This book is going to be printed, but it just needs a little boost to cover some of the costs.  
UPDATE (06/12/15): The Chronicles of Era: Book 1 has been completed and printed.  Donations now go towards getting the book into the hands of readers (contributors and beyond), towards future print runs, promotion and keeping the fire going for Book 2 (ETA: Fall 2016). 
The Flexible Funding Goal was $2000. A Little more than half of the money went to printing of the books, a quarter to shipping costs, and the remainder went to some marketing, fees and taxes. Whatever is earned will help to cover any or all of these costs. This campaign is an opportunity for you to help bring this creation to life and to get a copy of it in your hands. 

Perks

UPDATE (06/12/15): Please note that shipping costs have been added to several of the perks.  As always, Perks can be mixed and matched (example: adding a digital copy to perk for USA, etc). Bring any questions to my attention.
I am including a variety of Perks that will include original art from me, in addition to a copy of the graphic novel. Some might be just a quick sketch on the inside cover, or an 8"x10" black and white line drawing, to  more complicated original black and white art pieces that will be printed in colour.  Any original art offered will be pencilled and inked on Blueline Pro paper.

Post Cards

With all Perks you will receive one of eight 5x7 prints featuring scenes from the world of Era.

The backs of the post cards have space for a sketch, like these: 

Maybe you'll receive a sketch of something from future stories!



Original Art!

Some of the Perks you will receive original art from the world of Era!  
All art pieces will be drawn and inked on BlueLine Comic Art boards (8x10's will but cut down from the 11x17 sheets).  With the exception of the $200 perk, I will choose what character to illustrate, but if you say you really want to see someone, there's certainly no harm in asking.  The art and sketches will usually just depict the character, with some background details or accents, but not likely to be super complicated background.
Some samples of what some of the original may look like (black&white, single figure):



    Risks & Challenges

    Every project has potential risks and challenges, however a large portion of the work is already complete, so these risks are minimized.  Right now, the biggest obstacle is getting the book to print in time for C4.  The book will be printed either way, but C4 will offer me an opportunity to promote it and get it into even more hands. 

    Every contribution made will a help smooth the road to publication and allow more people to access this book.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If this project is not to your tastes then let me thank you for taking the time to read about it. But, if you know people that might be interested in The Chronicles of Era, please share it. Share this campaign, send links to my WordPress site or twitter handle (@ouroboros09).  There are a variety of tools for sharing and links available. 


    Thank you for your time and any help you can provide!


    Keep creative!

    Scott

The backs of the post cards have space for a sketch, like these: 




Maybe you'll receive a sketch of something from future stories!

If this project is not to your tastes then let me thank you for taking the time to read about it. But, if you know people that might be interested in The Chronicles of Era, please share it. Share this campaign, send links to my WordPress site or twitter handle (@ouroboros09).  There are a variety of tools for sharing and links available. Thank you for your time and any help you can provide!Keep creative!Scott

story:
What is operation dollhouse?

Operation dollhouse is a campaign for the little girl that lives inside each and everyone of us.

  • My name is Jørn, and I've been wanting a dollhouse since last friday.
  • The dollhouse costs about 200$ (500$ was minimum for the campaign, all profit will be used to buying beer.
  • I would be incredibly happy for all contributes, even if you donate only a Deutsch Mark. 

Cool, eh?

What do I need? And what do you get?

  • I need 200$ (More is just a bonus)
  • All contributors will get a hug, if you live in another country you will get a hug through e-mail. And a picture of me playing with my dolls.
  • If i don't reach my goal all money will go to Amnesty International (www.amnesty.org) because they work for human rights. And it really is a human right to own a dollhouse.
story_txt:
What is operation dollhouse?Operation dollhouse is a campaign for the little girl that lives inside each and everyone of us.
My name is Jørn, and I've been wanting a dollhouse since last friday.
The dollhouse costs about 200$ (500$ was minimum for the campaign, all profit will be used to buying beer.
I would be incredibly happy for all contributes, even if you donate only a Deutsch Mark. 
Cool, eh?What do I need? And what do you get?
I need 200$ (More is just a bonus)
All contributors will get a hug, if you live in another country you will get a hug through e-mail. And a picture of me playing with my dolls.
If i don't reach my goal all money will go to Amnesty International (www.amnesty.org) because they work for human rights. And it really is a human right to own a dollhouse.

story:
We have  shooting photos for our first Comic book for the Viseratta series. We are bringing the book characters to life. There will be a 250 limited edition print run of the first comic along with a pdf e-book file available.

Only 50 will have an extra insert hand signed.

Enter into the world of the Viseratta, the first Comic book edition by Ellen Griffin based off the Viseratta series.

There are unexplainable things that happen in this world, these are the things that change us forever


The Viseratta Series:

By Ellen Griffin

There are things in this world we will never understand, in darkness there is a madness that overtakes all human instinct. Leaving behind the ideals we know, and entering into a primal world of the Viseratta.


Viseratta is a paranormal tale of a transformation into darkness, horror, strength and the truth about the humanity. The true nature of what we are and what we can become, there is always a choice.

Ari has always been different but after a series of unexplainable terrifying events she comes face to face with what she truly is. For Ari and her friends, life as they know it will never be the same, when they get pulled into a world were nothing and no one is what they seem.

As the darkness clears and the secrets of the Viseratta unfold, they face the deadly creatures forged from fire, in an epic struggle that spans several generations between humans and demons.

to see weekly updates visit our website at  http://www.viseratta.com/sponsor.html

as we post pictures from the Comic Book and Book trailers


New drawings for the actual comic


About The Cover Artist:

Featuring Comic and cover Artist Jonathan Hatcher,


Born and raised in Boones Mill, Virginia, Johnathan Hatcher is a published illustrator, tattoo artist, and graphic designer. Previously working for Litter Box Comics on “A Necessary Evil”.

He now specializes in custom tattoo's ranging from cartoon to realism and has been inking at Cherry bomb tattoos since 2006.

Currently, he has been re-recruited back into the comic world for the first release of the Viseratta Comic.

------------------------------------

About The Author:

Fantasy Artist Ellen Griffin


Born on the New Jersey shore early enough to remember the 80's and big hair days and smart enough to hide all those embarrassing pictures. Then transplanted to the good ole' southern State of Virginia.

Currently a fantasy art artist and author, which is a pretty cool gig considering the fact she can change people into most any type of creature in a digital picture. However, one should not forget the not so hilarious sarcasm of hiding people of whom she has had differences with in her books. While most do make for some very interesting characters they do seem to meet some unusual fates. It does, however, make for some good reads!

www.viseratta.com

------------------------------------

About The Comic Artist:

Comic Artist Daniel Kelly


We have no idea where he came from. He originally just showed up one day to sing in a band. Currently, a Graphic Artist with a taste and flare for Anime Art.

Daniel was brought in to balance out the Viseratta Comic art, mixing the Heavy Metal style with Fantasy and Anime to make for a very interesting finished product.

He is currently banned from using any squid or octopus in the finished product. 

Main Characters Ashley Russell - as  Ari 

Mark Lepisto - as Erick

Mel Heflin - as Eva


What We Need & What You Get :

All of the work required to create the Viseratta Comic is currently being done and some initial work has already been completed. Our next shoot is April 17th to bring the main characters to life and then the artists will do what they do best. We just need a little more capital to actually print and manufacture the finished product. Our target is to raise $2,125.00 to make The Viseratta Comic a reality.

The cost break-down is:

Printing - Layouts - Art= $1,200.00

Costs of Perks = $525.00 and shipping of perks

Cushion = IndieGoGo takes a commission + a unexpected thing or two

Make an Impact:

In order to get published one has to be published, and so with our cool perks and your sponsorship everyone wins. Lets make this happen!

Other Ways You Can Help:

Do you know someone who might like to be involved in our project? Please let them know!

You can use Indiegogo's "Share Tools" to get the word out and help make this endeavor a success.

Thank you

story:
Imaginarium X: The NaviFlower Murder

The annual NaviFlower festival has begun! The citizens of Meedajuj on planet Imaginarium X are celebrating the source of energy for their city: the NaviFlower. But when a disgruntled citizen named Moonk becomes insecure about the superiority of the NaviFlower, he decides to take matters into his own hands and chop it down. After realizing his mistake, he leaves town.
When the rest of the city realizes what happened and the impact it will have on their town, they try to find him and seek revenge. But will they be able to find his whereabouts?

Why I Need Help & What You Get

The book will be 44 pages, and I need to pay to have them professionally printed. Since my budget is very limited, I need your help! I plan on also printing larger posters of individual pages from the book, which will be expensive.
I need all of this done by April 20th, 2015 in order to have my senior thesis show and graduate college.

Of course, with your contribution you will receive a copy of the book, and/or a poster or original art, depending on the amount you contribute.

Thank you! I appreciate all of you.

If you'd like to see more preview pages from the book or have any questions, feel free to contact me at toryerpenbeck@gmail.com

story:
Machine Time

"Why a comic?" you might ask. Because -- trust me! -- it's never too late to get into comics. But then, "Why another dystopian comic raging against the system?" Because this is also a story about dreamscapes, forgotten forests, and the power of memory.

How I fell into the nerdy comics universe ...

While I wish I could tell you that I was one of those sweet, geeky kids, who was mail ordering floppy comics to read after school, I grew up in a small town in Bavaria where nerdy kids were into archaeology museums rather than comic worlds. Marvel and DC were foreign words to me until I moved to the United States, where I finally discovered the unique pleasure of reading comic books and graphic novels.

Long before I got into comics though, I've been making art. Those who know me have seen my drawings, lino cuts, and screen prints, and two or three close friends have even elected to ink their bodies with my art (yes, I design tattoos!). While all this has been going on quietly, as a sidekick (so to speak) to my academic career, I've never really put myself out there and claimed the identity of an "artist."

I first delved into comic books while still teaching at the university. Over the past three years in particular, reading and writing comics offered a wonderful respite as well as, at times, an inspiration for my teaching (like that one time when we read Joe Sacco's "Palestine" in my class on Archaeologies of Colonialism). Now, newly arrived in New York City and at a sort of crossroads in my life, I'm launching myself full force into the weird and wild world of comics.

How I make my comics ... and what I need to make them:

There are piles of paper stacked next to me as I'm typing this: loose pages, sketchbooks, note pads. Some sheets are crowded with tiny text boxes and the outlines of story ideas, while others carry rough thumbnails and dainty sketches of story panels. Comic production takes concentration and time, as well as supplies and tools, plus the money to buy them. While all my comics are entirely hand drawn, the finished comic gets scanned and digitized, and the final touches are made on the computer.

For this purpose, I use a computer that's on its last leg, and I keep purchasing more drawing pads, pens, pencils, ink, and other stray art supplies. As with so many other things in this world, art isn't exactly a cheap endeavor, which is why it often feels like a luxury to me. However, it should be treated as a communal luxury. Let comics be a pleasure to be shared with friends, comrades, companions, lovers, fans, and devotees. Maybe there are also others -- outsiders, strangers, aliens, and all the nerdy kids yearning to be truly cool -- who will come across this campaign and find something in it that resonates with them, something worth throwing a few dollars at in return for a compelling story. So, here’s to hope.

The $$$ side of the amazing world of comics ...

Now, after all this talk about stories and dreams, I need to get practical for a moment and bring this back to how self-publishing works, and how you can help me with it. So let me break this down in terms of what has to happen in order to move this comic to physical production. As of now, the comic is fully conceptualized, drawn, inked, scanned, and laid out, so it's ready to go to the press whenever you are!

Over the next 3-4 weeks, I will be raising the necessary funds to get this comic printed and distributed, so that you can hold an actual hard copy of it in your hands by late January or early February 2017. In short, here's what I'm asking for:

  • ca. $400 to print 200 copies of the comic (and more on demand if extra money rolls in)
  • ca. $200 for shipping supplies (envelopes, card board, etc.) and mailing to get the comic + perks for backers out into the world
  • $150 to cover the hours a graphic designer spent on page layout + final design
  • ca. $150 for promotional materials, including 1-year rental of a P.O. box, for returns and responses
  • ca. $100 for art supplies for future comics, lino prints, etc.

Makes a total of around $1000. While I think this is pretty straightforward, let me try to answer at least two questions that might come up as you're reading this:

First, what happens if I don't raise the necessary funds to realize this project? It's simple: If I raise enough to cover at least the printing costs, I will go ahead with the project anyways, though it'll be significantly more challenging. I might not be able to send hard copies to all backers, but you will still get your exclusive e-copy. I will also distribute the comic in local bookstores, so you can mail order physical copies from these distributors.

Second, what happens if I raise more funds than I’m asking for? That'd be amazing, of course, and the answer is even simpler: I'll be making more comics! I've several drafts of comics sitting at home, and more exciting ideas for stories that are still unfolding. Some future comics to look forward to include a narrative about politics in Turkey as well as a silent comic about love and a bonsai tree.

Because capitalism is not a love story ...

To be entirely honest: Pitching a call for a fundraising campaign is a little bit frightening, especially for a project of the heart. I know that a lot of other people, too, are struggling -- to make rent, to find a steady job, or to treat themselves to the occasional luxury (going to the movies, eating out, buying a comic). So I encourage you to give only what you can. Anything helps, and even the smallest donation will receive an electronic copy of the comic in return.

Still, if you really cannot contribute, but are intrigued by the possibilities of this project, that doesn't mean you can't help. Those of you on social media sites can easily spread the word with the click of a button. And if you're feeling more like an explorer, there's also a SQUIRREL PRESS Instagram page where you can preview some of my work and, believe it or not, a Tumblr website full of serious and not-so-serious little stories.

Let the sharing begin, because, as they say, sharing is caring. And: Thank you. So so much.

Maresi, Squirrel-in-Chief @ SQUIRREL PRESS

story:
"We shall not fail or falter; we shall not weaken or tire...Give us the tools and we will finish the job." Sir Winston Churchill

I make underground comix and art as do many in my small creative community; I've been doing this since 1993 in good times and bad.  And while I'm not fighting the Nazis during the Blitz, in my own small way, my comics, in the words Woody Guthrie's guitar used to have painted on it, "kills fascism."

My name's Richard Van Ingram and I'm an artist with a studio degree in printmaking and an MA in philosophy.  I taught ethics at the university level for four years; I worked in public mental health for ten.  For day jobs I've done everything from selling used books to tattooing, picture framing, and cooking.  Yes, I've scrubbed my share of toilets; I've worked in a nursing home with the dying.  I've taught young officers entering the military the difference between a moral decision and an expedient one -- and which they ought to choose and why.

But at age 48, I've never made a living off my art, which is my desire -- and the deficit isn't because of poor quality (see my website and judge for yourself) but a combination of circumstances.

First, the business model of the 2000s; One must show and give away one's work for free online in hopes people will buy a book or some swag.  Imagine a financial advisor or other worker in any other profession attempting to make a living by first giving away their their work and then hoping the recipient will show some financial appreciation for it.  Could you make a decent, even lower middle class life that way?  Pay for insurance?  Raise kids, make a house payment?

Secondly, most of the publishing houses that would hire or print freelance artists or independent creators folded in between the financial crises of 2001 and 2008.  That leaves the rest of us scrambling to either work for the conglomerates owned by Disney (Marvel Comics) or Time Warner (DC Comics) -- and neither of them are interested in anything that offers a critique of modern society,  genuine satire, or real adult content -- everything is aimed at overgrown adolescent tastes or pure entertainment.  No protest, no biting commentary: nothing, in fact, a comic book is capable of delivering in its unique combination of language and images.

Third, this leaves independents such as myself who do not do superhero fantasies or happy-ending sci fi to fend for ourselves and compete with these media behemoths.  Needless to say, our audiences are small.  Not because we are boring or cheezy or amateurish, but because we are small and because Diamond Distribution -- the monopoly that distributes comics and is in bed with the large companies -- locks out small entrepreneurs with something to say and share from distribution to direct sales comics shops: the main line of income for most creators.

Fourth, because of the cultural climate and its swing to the right over the past 30 years, many printers will not touch or distribute online material that is the least bit controversial: in language; nudity; content; message.  I'm not talking child porn, but simple art and adult notions.  Things that are perfectly acceptable in the artistic and literary world at large are somehow forbidden in the comics world for fear "the children" will get their hands on it.  As if a child couldn't read a Henry Miller or get their hands on Playboy (and have for decades with little negative consequence beyond the development of an interesting vocabulary).

We undergrounders scrape to publish small runs of comics we must peddle ourselves online, by driving them around to stores willing to take a few., and by lugging them to conventions.  The printers charge a great deal of money per book for short runs and our profit margins are miniscule; many of us make nothing whatsoever after spending what can be upwards of a hundred hours putting together a book by ourselves, doing the graphic design, lettering, coloring, art, and writing.

All for the privilege of free speech and bringing an audience a superior product or a different point of view.

So, what do I expect, a Free Ride?!  Artists are supposed to suffer, aren't they?

Suffering is inevitable and expected.  No one does anything worthwhile without paying for it in time and talent and paying their dues.  That's life and I'm not protesting reality here.

What I am asking for is this: Contributions so I can publish my comics and offer cheap printing for a circle of talented artists in the same shape I'm in -- not dilettantes who have not paid their dues or lack suffering, not kids straight out of college, not hacks.  Folks who need access to the press, and the only way you get freedom of the press without going broke or suffering the whims of a printer is to actually own the press.  Like Mark Twain, back in the day, who was doing essentially what we do, sans pictures.

I want my small company, Loser Comix Group, to expand slightly by buying a used CMYK printer capable of printing comics.  In return, I can print my own books affordably, on demand, and offer small run printing to a few other creators at highly affordable rates competitive with the online companies that presently control our output.  

As a civil libertarian, I will not exercise draconian editorial opposition to content.  No, I will not print child porn or gratuitous violence against women, for example, or hate speech.  But outside such bracketed material, I will print what the creators want to take responsibility for on their own, neither approving nor disapproving.   That should be the nature of a free printing press, I think, in a free society. Certainly it's what the second generation of the underground and alternative comics movement needs. 

I have located a refurbished  Xerox DC 252-type machine the dealer is willing to sell for between $9,000 and $10,000.  The $9,500 I'm seeking would pay for the majority of the machine after Indiegogo takes its cut and I will raise the remaining money, including shipping and supplies, out of my own pocket by borrowing against my car, from a partner who has pledged a generous amount, and by selling some of my art and belongings.

In the end, I will train myself to run the press, fulfill orders in a timely manner, and split my time between making my own work and helping others spread their message and reach their artistic dreams.  Working a 14-18 hour day is no new thing for me and doing so to make this project an ongoing concern would be a pleasure for me.  Your money won't be wasted.

The Perks 

The first 300 people donating $5.00 or more will receive a free copy of my Jack T. Chick parody propaganda comic, FREE YOUR ASS, YOUR MIND WILL FOLLOW, signed.

The first 100 people to contribute at least $20.00 or more will receive a free printed issue of LOSER COMIX #1 signed by yours truly.

The first 100 people to contribute $100.00 or more will receive a full-color poster, specially designed and drawn for this project and signed by me.  Only 100 of these posters will ever be printed.

The first 10 people to contribute at least $500.00 or more will receive an original, unique watercolor, 11 x 17, on Arches paper.  Yep, I'll sign it.

The first person to donate $1000.00 or more will have their name printed on the cover of LOSER COMIX #2 as my special benefactor and receive a page of original art from the issue, signed (with my undying gratitude).  Yes, you get a copy of the book, too.

But what if you don't meet the funding goal?

Simple.  I'll use the money to buy the press anyway -- I'll just have to borrow more, work harder, save more, and it will take longer.  But I WILL get this project done.  I can get it done more effectively and faster with your help; but free speech and expression will need me to serve them even if you don't or can't.  I'm committed.  I have to make this work -- it's my life's vocation.  

The Impact

Maybe you think comics don't make much difference in the world or are of slight cultural import.  How wrong you are.

You are thinking about commercial entertainment comics made for conglomerate profits and to sell movies and merchandise.  

For example, take Christian Fundamentalist underground cartoonist Jack T. Chick.  By now, nearly everyone in America has at one or another time found one of his little comics designed as pure propaganda to sell conspiracy theories, End-of-the-World horror tales, hatred of the LGBT community, women's rights, an angry deity prepared to destroy the souls of anyone who doesn't believe what old Jack is selling by way of theology -- all that and more in 16 or so black and white pages in dozens and dozens of comics pamphlets.

Jack's been doing these things for decades.  He has his own press. He and one other illustrator do all the creative work and his company distributes these things by the hundreds cheaply to anyone who wants them to give away and spread the word.

Chick got the idea from Chinese Communists when he served as a Marine in the Pacific in WWII.  The Chinese used similar comics pamphlets to explain the basics of revolutionary thought to illiterate and partly literate peasants to great effect.  Jack thought, "If they can use the pamphlets for Communism, I could use them for my form of Christianity."  

Years later, Jack T. Chick has been extremely effective at spreading all sorts of beliefs, from the notion reading Harry Potter or playing D&D leads to occultism and demonic possession to the notion the Jesuits are secretly trying to take over the world and enthrone a pope as The Antichrist.   And that Freemasons are devil-worshippers, rock-and-roll will send you to Hell, and that one drink of alcohol will render you a miserable drug addict for life.

That's just scratching the surface.  JTC has been thoroughly effective at moulding and influencing many aspects of American culture.  All with little 16 page comics handed out by an army of volunteer true believers.

Comics can't affect the culture?   Don't you believe it.  They can be powerful tools capable of delivering any sort of message or artistic idea cheaply to a mass, post literate world.

Art Spiegelman, on the other hand, has used the medium to explore the Holocaust and its generational effects in his seminal, Pulitzer-winning Maus.   A deep, serious exploration of one of the most morally reprehensible chapters in human history, Spiegelman employed pictures and words to face man's inhumanity and all too human features for a literate audience.  He kept the memory of his father, a survivor, alive for all time in honest ink.

Help me buy a press and publish books that are more like Spiegelman's and in opposition to Chick's insane, hate-filled rage against the Enlightenment.  I've been making such works for years and there are others waiting to do and distribute the same -- all that holds us back is press access and places willing to sell our messages and art.

Give us the tools; we'll do the work in the name of civil liberties and the erosion of authoritarianism. 

    Risks & Challenges

    The main risk is locating our audience and putting the books into their hands easily.  Direct sales comics shops will sometimes take a risk on undergrounds, but usually the clientele won't.  They're looking for conglomocomics and collectible figures, cards, and so on -- the usual fan boy paraphernalia. However, there are alternatives that are being researched and approached.

    Shops specializing in pot-related material -- "smoke shops" and shops in states where marijuana is now legal -- are likely allies.  In the '60s and '70s, the old head shops were, in fact, the original points of distribution for first generation underground books, posters, and comix.  Naturally open to items promoting civil liberties, such shops seem one of the better venues to sell the printed comix:  The audience is there and some artists cater to them directly.

    Small, independent bookstores and used bookstores are a lesser possibility.

    There remains the network of comic book conventions -- being booked as guests or buying dealer's tables.    This also allows people like me to meet and speak with actual humans who may be interested in our books or in having their own work printed.

    And there is the internet where many of us maintain websites we can sell from directly and advertise our endeavours.  I maintain mine at www.losercomix.com

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Can't contribute to the cause but think it's important?  Your efforts to talk up this effort is just as important as money to me.  Use the "share" tools to let people know you support access to a free press for some folks who'll use it right.  Encourage others to take a look and consider helping out.  Talk about the issues of free speech, art, and sharing a variety of messages in the marketplaces.  

      Any help whatsoever you offer me will be worth more than I can ever tell you.
story_txt: "We shall not fail or falter; we shall not weaken or tire...Give us the tools and we will finish the job." Sir Winston Churchill I make underground comix and art as do many in my small creative community; I've been doing this since 1993 in good times and bad.  And while I'm not fighting the Nazis during the Blitz, in my own small way, my comics, in the words Woody Guthrie's guitar used to have painted on it, "kills fascism."My name's Richard Van Ingram and I'm an artist with a studio degree in printmaking and an MA in philosophy.  I taught ethics at the university level for four years; I worked in public mental health for ten.  For day jobs I've done everything from selling used books to tattooing, picture framing, and cooking.  Yes, I've scrubbed my share of toilets; I've worked in a nursing home with the dying.  I've taught young officers entering the military the difference between a moral decision and an expedient one -- and which they ought to choose and why.But at age 48, I've never made a living off my art, which is my desire -- and the deficit isn't because of poor quality (see my website and judge for yourself) but a combination of circumstances.First, the business model of the 2000s; One must show and give away one's work for free online in hopes people will buy a book or some swag.  Imagine a financial advisor or other worker in any other profession attempting to make a living by first giving away their their work and then hoping the recipient will show some financial appreciation for it.  Could you make a decent, even lower middle class life that way?  Pay for insurance?  Raise kids, make a house payment?Secondly, most of the publishing houses that would hire or print freelance artists or independent creators folded in between the financial crises of 2001 and 2008.  That leaves the rest of us scrambling to either work for the conglomerates owned by Disney (Marvel Comics) or Time Warner (DC Comics) -- and neither of them are interested in anything that offers a critique of modern society,  genuine satire, or real adult content -- everything is aimed at overgrown adolescent tastes or pure entertainment.  No protest, no biting commentary: nothing, in fact, a comic book is capable of delivering in its unique combination of language and images.Third, this leaves independents such as myself who do not do superhero fantasies or happy-ending sci fi to fend for ourselves and compete with these media behemoths.  Needless to say, our audiences are small.  Not because we are boring or cheezy or amateurish, but because we are small and because Diamond Distribution -- the monopoly that distributes comics and is in bed with the large companies -- locks out small entrepreneurs with something to say and share from distribution to direct sales comics shops: the main line of income for most creators.Fourth, because of the cultural climate and its swing to the right over the past 30 years, many printers will not touch or distribute online material that is the least bit controversial: in language; nudity; content; message.  I'm not talking child porn, but simple art and adult notions.  Things that are perfectly acceptable in the artistic and literary world at large are somehow forbidden in the comics world for fear "the children" will get their hands on it.  As if a child couldn't read a Henry Miller or get their hands on Playboy (and have for decades with little negative consequence beyond the development of an interesting vocabulary).We undergrounders scrape to publish small runs of comics we must peddle ourselves online, by driving them around to stores willing to take a few., and by lugging them to conventions.  The printers charge a great deal of money per book for short runs and our profit margins are miniscule; many of us make nothing whatsoever after spending what can be upwards of a hundred hours putting together a book by ourselves, doing the graphic design, lettering, coloring, art, and writing.All for the privilege of free speech and bringing an audience a superior product or a different point of view.   So, what do I expect, a Free Ride?!  Artists are supposed to suffer, aren't they? Suffering is inevitable and expected.  No one does anything worthwhile without paying for it in time and talent and paying their dues.  That's life and I'm not protesting reality here.What I am asking for is this: Contributions so I can publish my comics and offer cheap printing for a circle of talented artists in the same shape I'm in -- not dilettantes who have not paid their dues or lack suffering, not kids straight out of college, not hacks.  Folks who need access to the press, and the only way you get freedom of the press without going broke or suffering the whims of a printer is to actually own the press.  Like Mark Twain, back in the day, who was doing essentially what we do, sans pictures.I want my small company, Loser Comix Group, to expand slightly by buying a used CMYK printer capable of printing comics.  In return, I can print my own books affordably, on demand, and offer small run printing to a few other creators at highly affordable rates competitive with the online companies that presently control our output.  As a civil libertarian, I will not exercise draconian editorial opposition to content.  No, I will not print child porn or gratuitous violence against women, for example, or hate speech.  But outside such bracketed material, I will print what the creators want to take responsibility for on their own, neither approving nor disapproving.   That should be the nature of a free printing press, I think, in a free society. Certainly it's what the second generation of the underground and alternative comics movement needs. I have located a refurbished  Xerox DC 252-type machine the dealer is willing to sell for between $9,000 and $10,000.  The $9,500 I'm seeking would pay for the majority of the machine after Indiegogo takes its cut and I will raise the remaining money, including shipping and supplies, out of my own pocket by borrowing against my car, from a partner who has pledged a generous amount, and by selling some of my art and belongings.In the end, I will train myself to run the press, fulfill orders in a timely manner, and split my time between making my own work and helping others spread their message and reach their artistic dreams.  Working a 14-18 hour day is no new thing for me and doing so to make this project an ongoing concern would be a pleasure for me.  Your money won't be wasted.The Perks The first 300 people donating $5.00 or more will receive a free copy of my Jack T. Chick parody propaganda comic, FREE YOUR ASS, YOUR MIND WILL FOLLOW, signed.The first 100 people to contribute at least $20.00 or more will receive a free printed issue of LOSER COMIX #1 signed by yours truly.The first 100 people to contribute $100.00 or more will receive a full-color poster, specially designed and drawn for this project and signed by me.  Only 100 of these posters will ever be printed.The first 10 people to contribute at least $500.00 or more will receive an original, unique watercolor, 11 x 17, on Arches paper.  Yep, I'll sign it.The first person to donate $1000.00 or more will have their name printed on the cover of LOSER COMIX #2 as my special benefactor and receive a page of original art from the issue, signed (with my undying gratitude).  Yes, you get a copy of the book, too.But what if you don't meet the funding goal?Simple.  I'll use the money to buy the press anyway -- I'll just have to borrow more, work harder, save more, and it will take longer.  But I WILL get this project done.  I can get it done more effectively and faster with your help; but free speech and expression will need me to serve them even if you don't or can't.  I'm committed.  I have to make this work -- it's my life's vocation.     The Impact Maybe you think comics don't make much difference in the world or are of slight cultural import.  How wrong you are.You are thinking about commercial entertainment comics made for conglomerate profits and to sell movies and merchandise.  For example, take Christian Fundamentalist underground cartoonist Jack T. Chick.  By now, nearly everyone in America has at one or another time found one of his little comics designed as pure propaganda to sell conspiracy theories, End-of-the-World horror tales, hatred of the LGBT community, women's rights, an angry deity prepared to destroy the souls of anyone who doesn't believe what old Jack is selling by way of theology -- all that and more in 16 or so black and white pages in dozens and dozens of comics pamphlets.Jack's been doing these things for decades.  He has his own press. He and one other illustrator do all the creative work and his company distributes these things by the hundreds cheaply to anyone who wants them to give away and spread the word.Chick got the idea from Chinese Communists when he served as a Marine in the Pacific in WWII.  The Chinese used similar comics pamphlets to explain the basics of revolutionary thought to illiterate and partly literate peasants to great effect.  Jack thought, "If they can use the pamphlets for Communism, I could use them for my form of Christianity."  Years later, Jack T. Chick has been extremely effective at spreading all sorts of beliefs, from the notion reading Harry Potter or playing D&D leads to occultism and demonic possession to the notion the Jesuits are secretly trying to take over the world and enthrone a pope as The Antichrist.   And that Freemasons are devil-worshippers, rock-and-roll will send you to Hell, and that one drink of alcohol will render you a miserable drug addict for life.That's just scratching the surface.  JTC has been thoroughly effective at moulding and influencing many aspects of American culture.  All with little 16 page comics handed out by an army of volunteer true believers.Comics can't affect the culture?   Don't you believe it.  They can be powerful tools capable of delivering any sort of message or artistic idea cheaply to a mass, post literate world.Art Spiegelman, on the other hand, has used the medium to explore the Holocaust and its generational effects in his seminal, Pulitzer-winning Maus.   A deep, serious exploration of one of the most morally reprehensible chapters in human history, Spiegelman employed pictures and words to face man's inhumanity and all too human features for a literate audience.  He kept the memory of his father, a survivor, alive for all time in honest ink.Help me buy a press and publish books that are more like Spiegelman's and in opposition to Chick's insane, hate-filled rage against the Enlightenment.  I've been making such works for years and there are others waiting to do and distribute the same -- all that holds us back is press access and places willing to sell our messages and art.Give us the tools; we'll do the work in the name of civil liberties and the erosion of authoritarianism.   Risks & Challenges The main risk is locating our audience and putting the books into their hands easily.  Direct sales comics shops will sometimes take a risk on undergrounds, but usually the clientele won't.  They're looking for conglomocomics and collectible figures, cards, and so on -- the usual fan boy paraphernalia. story:
My name is Rising Crow.  I’m an artist with Cerebral Palsy from Williamsport, PA. Due to my CP, I lack the coordination in my hands to paint.  Therefore, I attach paintbrushes to baseball caps and paint with my head.  My gallery called Rising Crow Gallery Inc. is located in downtown Williamsport PA and not only features my work, but also the works of other artists with disabilities. I am comfortable living in Williamsport and have many friends both inside and outside of the artist community  that have helped me tremendously.   However, my roots and family are in Asheville, North Carolina and I wish to return to my family.  Asheville also has a very well established and thriving artist community which is an added bonus for me to relocate.

  My goal is  $25,000 to cover the first year’s worth of living expenses in Asheville including studio/gallery space rental, my salary, supplies, and advertising.  Hopefully, the gallery will enable other artists with disabilities to also become established.  Feel free to email me for answers to specific questions about the project or to receive a high quality print of one of my acrylic paintings with a donation of $25 or more.  Email me at ironmonk68@yahoo.com   Thank you for your support.

story:
the project

after creating a comic book on the iPad, i've learned all the "do's and don'ts" and i'm sharing them in this book. the book walks you through the process of creating your next  comic book on the iPad and covers everything from basic drawing principles, page layout, inking, coloring and lettering. i share my personal tool selection, settings, workflow, marketing strategy and i explain the benefits and disadvantages of both the digital market and the traditional print market. i feel that all artist, but especially independent artist, can benefit from drawing on the iPad because it saves time, saves money and it removes some of the fear artist experience when releasing their work for the first time. this book will open up the door for many artist who haven't made a comic book yet due to the expenses that used to be involved.

the funding

the money raised is for my first print run. i have some print proofs coming in the mail and will post photos once they arrive around September 5th. my secondary goal is to get the book into book stores and class rooms for the young comic book creators of tomorrow. kids producing comics on the iPad at younger ages will allow them to explore the process, develop story telling skills and release their comic books digitally.

about the artist

i grew up around comic books and always wanted to create one myself. like many independent comic creators, i was faced with a problem. making a comic book in full color can get a little expensive. art supplies, scanners, drawing tablets, photoshop...the list goes on.

after seeing some of the amazing art that had been created on the iPad i decided to try and create some myself. the first drawing i created on the iPad was this one. it gave me hope that it was possible to draw on the iPad, but how far could you push it?

after much trouble shooting, i quickly understood that it was possible to create art that was no different than what i could do with pen, paper and photoshop. take this batman illustration for example -

i ended up creating my comic book, including lettering it, all on the iPad and released it at Chicago Con this month. it has since been sold to readers around the world. sjcpanda.blogspot.com

story:
What Is Galaxion?

Galaxion is a multi-part science fiction graphic novel. The story is told first on the web, with pages published weekly and then collected into print form. We’re ready to print the third volume and you can help us make that happen!

The graphic novel tells the story of the crew of the starship Galaxion, who are testing a new jump engine. They make the jump, but don’t end up where they expect. The story has adventure, humour, romance and mystery. It appeals to readers of all ages and fans of ensemble cast science fiction shows like Star Trek (although those who watched Star Blazers may notice some influence, too).

As Volume 3 begins, the crew has made their way to a planet that looks too much like Earth to be a coincidence, but is different enough so that they know they are somewhere else. On the surface of the planet they find the wreck of the Hiawatha, a previous ship that had attempted to make the jump years before. They also find two distinct bands of human-like natives: one attacks them, then the other takes them prisoner. The ground party has lost contact with those still on the ship. 

If you want to see what it’s like, you can check it out at the Galaxion website. We think that’ll convince you. But many readers agree, it reads even better in print form.

This year is something of an anniversary for Galaxion. It was 30 years ago this year that Tara and her friend Wendy first assembled the crew of the Galaxion and started telling their tales. It was 20 years ago, at the Chicago Comicon in 1993, that the comic was first printed (photocopied) and sold. Later in the 90s it graduated to full-size printed comic format and was properly distributed for several years. In  2006 a new, improved version was launched on the web, which we are collecting now.

Help us celebrate Galaxion’s 20th (or 30th!) birthday by contributing to the publication of this volume!

What We Need

We’re looking for $4,000. That will enable us to print and ship the graphic novels without going into debt. If we reach that, great! If we exceed that, even better! If we don’t reach it, we’ll still print the books and send the perks. But not only will we get less in total, we get less of what you contribute as Indiegogo takes a bigger cut. It will just mean a lot more scrimping for the family.

Don't worry about the currency. We take lots of different ones. Indiegogo/Paypal handles the conversion.

To help inspire you to getting us to our goal, we are going to add incentives as the campaign runs and we hit percentage targets. I’ll say a bit more about that below, in the next section.

What You Get


No matter what you donate, you are part of the Galaxion Volume 3 publishing team. That said, we all love perks and you can see a range of them over to the side. I won’t repeat them all here, but I do want to highlight a few:

  • $25 is an important level. That’s where you get the printed book (signed and personalized) as well as everything for the levels above.
  • $100 is for the art collectors (and game players). It gets you the original art for a Galaxion playing card. It takes the character sketch to a whole new level. There’s a limit of 54 of them, though (to allow for jokers). And, if we manage to get 52 takers, we’re committed to making them into real decks and we’ll send a deck along, too.
  • $250 is for the completists. There have been three different versions of Galaxion in print. This gets you all of them, as well as everything else we can lay our hands on that Tara published! (It also gets you an Amy Unbounded story from NYT bestselling and award-winning author Rachel Hartman (Seraphina)
  • $600 is for those who love to see themselves in print. Add yourself to the crew of the Galaxion!

In addition, we’ll be unlocking bonus perks to add to what you’re getting as we reach various milestones. Each time we reach a milestone, we’ll add it to the level and announce the next. To start off with, here’s the first:

  • When we are 50% funded, we’ll add e-books of volumes 1 and 2 for everyone who has supported at least $10. Instead of just getting volume 3, you get all of them. It should make it easier to catch up, if this campaign is your introduction to Galaxion. ACHIEVED!
  • When we are 75% funded, we'll add a couple of buttons and a bookmark for everyone who has supported at least $25. Tara has been working on diversifying her sales items for when she goes to conventons. One thing she’s been adding are buttons and bookmarks. Of course, there are Galaxion buttons. But there are other buttons as well: Fracking Geologists (in BSG font), EPIC FIAL, Save Ferris, Dendarii Mercenary or Ivan for Emperor, Big Damn Hero, Un(obtainium) or Ex(plodium), a whole raft of Minecraft buttons, etc. ACHIEVED!

  • When we are 100% funded we will add a signed colour print for everyone who has supported at least $100. The print will show a never-before-seen alternate of the painting that we used for the first printing of Volume 1 - one that Tara now says she prefers to the one we went with. ACHIEVED!
  • When we are 125% funded we will add a "Volume 3: In the Making" digital book (PDF) for everyone who has supported at least $10. What is this "In the Making" you ask? It's a collection of the script and all of the penciled pages that preceded the inked and toned pages that you'll already be getting. See how the story progressed from script to pencils to final inks - and what changed along the way. We've got the scripts. We've got scans of just about all of the pencils (we're missing a five page stretch, I admit, but we can fill at least some of that in with the thumbnails). And we'll see if we can find anything else good to throw in to make up for the missing pages. For anyone interested in the process of making comics, this is the perk bonus for you! ACHIEVED!
  • When we are 150% funded we will add a "Galaxion: The Salmagundi Years" digital book for everyone who has supported at least $10. As we say above, Galaxion got its as a comic start 20 years ago at the Chicago Comicon. Tara and her cousin Franz got together and produced a small photocopied comic called Salmagundi. It was a flip book with one side being Galaxion and the other side Franz's comic Vagabond. It ran for seven issues before Tara left to move to full-size professionally printed comics. I'll scan in the Galaxion stories from these issues so you can see how the comic got its start - and how far Tara has come! ACHIEVED!
  • When we are 175% funded we will have characters answer a question for everyone who has supported at least $50. As we've promised, all books will come signed and personalized. However, if you are at the Ensign level and above, you can submit a question (within reason) to one of the characters. Tara will sketch a small headshot of that character by the signature in Volume 3 and have him or her answer the question for you. ACHIEVED!
  • When we are 200% funded we will add a brand new GALAXION short story to the bundle for everyone who has supported at least $10. After Tara has completed all of the playing cards she has committed to drawing, she'll create the new GALAXION short story. We'll turn it into a PDF and send it along.

How you know the book will ship

This isn’t our first time printing Galaxion. This is Volume 3. We’ve done this twice before (more if you count earlier versions) and we know what it takes. The comics are all done. The book is assembled. We have the quote from the printer. All we are waiting for is your contribution to lighten the load and help pay the bills.

Other Ways You Can Help

But your financial contribution isn’t the only way you can help. We need all the help we can get spreading the word! Share the campaign on social media sites (Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Pinterest, Google+ or all of them). Send emails to friends and family with links to the Indiegogo page or the video. This is a great opportunity for people to join the ranks of Galaxion-readers – especially with that first bonus perk!
